body: This was done to respect `only` and `except` options. What is in your `except` configuration?
So are those rules preventing the filter to work, which is the reason, or those or not firing here and something is wrong with the CompositeAuth now?

The issue I'm having is not to do with except and only config. The issue is trying to do basic auth but the authentication function wasn't called because of the if statement added by this fix: https://github.com/yiisoft/yii2/blame/f72310c398759841a0f8b52e1aba7990086c0d9c/framework/filters/auth/CompositeAuth.php#L73

The if statement doesn't meet ($this->owner is null), the authenticate function doesn't get called, hence the authentication always fails. If line 73 and 78 commented out, it gets authenticated.

Downgrade to Yii V2.0.45 and it works.

issue.title: Fix CompositeAuth::authenticate()

repository.name: yii2
repository.description: Yii 2: The Fast, Secure and Professional PHP Framework

issue.body:
| Q             | A
| ------------- | ---
| Is bugfix?    | ✔️
| New feature?  | ❌
| Breaks BC?    | ❌
| Fixed issues  | #19517

body: @cwongwpp `$this->owner` can't be null, but  `action` property(`$this->owner->action`) not defined in `Module`

> @cwongwpp `$this->owner` can't be null, but `action` property(`$this->owner->action`) not defined in `Module`

Sorry, I don't understand this. What action needs to be defined? This has been working and breaks after upgrading to V2.0.46.
@cwongwpp #19418 is BC break because this changes support attaching only to controllers: `yii\base\Module` don't have `action` property.

If using `CompositeAuth` via config file then `$this->owner` is an instance of `yii\web\Application` and it don't have action property.

```
'as authenticator' => [
    'class' => CompositeAuth::class,
    'authMethods' => [
        ['class' => HttpBearerAuth::class],
    ]
],
```
@h0rseduck no matter via config or not

@WinterSilence 
Of course.  I just described another case

Sorry, i have the same problem. I was declaring the authenticator behavior into the behaviors function of the module. It is suposed to apply to every controller into that module but as @h0rseduck said `$this->owner` (in this case) is an instance of yii\web\Application and it don't have action property.

So instead of declaring the behavior into every controller, i came ahead with this temporary solution. Into my module `init` i do:
```
Yii::$app->on('beforeAction', fn() => Yii::$app->controller->attachBehavior('authenticator', [
    'class' => CompositeAuth::class,
    'authMethods' => [
        HttpBearerAuth::class,
    ],
]));
```

Now everything works properly. Please anyone can tell me if this is correct to do? Or should i declare the behavior into every controller instead?
